question.title: Can Java's NullPointerException be changed to report on which variable was null?

node.contents: Sadly no, it'd be useful though

astNode.text: Sadly no, it'd be useful though

node.contents: Isn't the line of code sufficient?

astNode.text: Isn't the line of code sufficient?

node.contents: @Lirik I presume the obvious answer is _yes_. When it comes to _spaghetti code_ the answer is _no_ I'm afraid...

astNode.text: @Lirik I presume the obvious answer is _yes_. When it comes to _spaghetti code_ the answer is _no_ I'm afraid...

node.contents: why don't you point debugger at that line of code and determine which variable is null. Is your code not structured properly so, that you have couple of variables in single line?

astNode.text: why don't you point debugger at that line of code and determine which variable is null. Is your code not structured properly so, that you have couple of variables in single line?

node.contents: @pankar if the code is such a spaghetti mess that one can't figure out which variable is `null` on a given line of code, then I would say there are **MUCH** bigger problems there.

astNode.text: @pankar if the code is such a spaghetti mess that one can't figure out which variable is `null` on a given line of code, then I would say there are **MUCH** bigger problems there.

node.contents: @pankar The problem really comes in chained method calls. If I have `something.getThis().getThat().getAnotherThing().whyAmIStillChaining().seriouslyWtf()` all on one line and get an NPE, the only easy way to figure it out is to pull it all apart and recompile/rerun. It's why I wish they had put the [Elvis operator](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4390141/java-operator-for-checking-null-what-is-it-not-ternary) in Java 7. Oh well. I had this problem recently too -.-

astNode.text: @pankar The problem really comes in chained method calls. If I have `something.getThis().getThat().getAnotherThing().whyAmIStillChaining().seriouslyWtf()` all on one line and get an NPE, the only easy way to figure it out is to pull it all apart and recompile/rerun. It's why I wish they had put the [Elvis operator](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4390141/java-operator-for-checking-null-what-is-it-not-ternary) in Java 7. Oh well. I had this problem recently too -.-

node.contents: Even if the call isn't chained like that, the actual (conceptual) error can be several calls away from where it was detected (perhaps by an API). (But I share a general distaste for "chained" calls, since they make debugging a bear and do not at all improve performance.)

astNode.text: Even if the call isn't chained like that, the actual (conceptual) error can be several calls away from where it was detected (perhaps by an API). (But I share a general distaste for "chained" calls, since they make debugging a bear and do not at all improve performance.)

node.contents: The NullPointerException in Java seems to only report that it occurred on a particular line of code. Is it possible to alter that exception to state which variable was null if there is more than one variable used in a line of code?

astNode.text: The NullPointerException in Java seems to only report that it occurred on a particular line of code. Is it possible to alter that exception to state which variable was null if there is more than one variable used in a line of code?

node.contents: What else is an NPE caused by?

astNode.text: What else is an NPE caused by?

node.contents: Ugh, iterating the cases would be rough. But it could be thrown as part of the guard pattern. Basically, a method that checks its arguments for `null` and then throws an NPE before doing work. For instance, some collections do this to avoid corrupting the data structure. Other application may be to just avoid the NPE happening organically.

astNode.text: Ugh, iterating the cases would be rough. But it could be thrown as part of the guard pattern. Basically, a method that checks its arguments for `null` and then throws an NPE before doing work. For instance, some collections do this to avoid corrupting the data structure. Other application may be to just avoid the NPE happening organically.

node.contents: A random terrible coder could throw an NPE for fun.

astNode.text: A random terrible coder could throw an NPE for fun.

node.contents: @DaveNewton You can also get an NPE from auto-boxing, such as doing `Integer val = null` and then passing it to `someMethod(int i)` like so: `someMethod(val);`

astNode.text: @DaveNewton You can also get an NPE from auto-boxing, such as doing `Integer val = null` and then passing it to `someMethod(int i)` like so: `someMethod(val);`

node.contents: So, all caused by a variable, except when thrown explicitly.

astNode.text: So, all caused by a variable, except when thrown explicitly.

node.contents: `throw null` too...

astNode.text: `throw null` too...

node.contents: No. NullPointerException does not always have to be caused by a variable/identifier being null. E.g. throw new NullPointerException() and throw null. Though it is often the case, it is not strictly required.

astNode.text: No. NullPointerException does not always have to be caused by a variable/identifier being null. E.g. throw new NullPointerException() and throw null. Though it is often the case, it is not strictly required.

node.contents: In most cases, it is fairly obvious what has caused the NPE. If not, then you may have too much going on in one line of code.

astNode.text: In most cases, it is fairly obvious what has caused the NPE. If not, then you may have too much going on in one line of code.

node.contents: Consider this use case:

astNode.text: Consider this use case:

node.contents: Here it is obvious that foo is `null.

astNode.text: Here it is obvious that foo is `null.

node.contents: Another case:

astNode.text: Another case:

node.contents: Here it could be foo, bar, or bar2.

astNode.text: Here it could be foo, bar, or bar2.

node.contents: The point is, that armed with this information and a breakpoint, it should be obvious what was null. If worse comes to worse, a static code analyzer like FindBugs could also give you some hints.

astNode.text: The point is, that armed with this information and a breakpoint, it should be obvious what was null. If worse comes to worse, a static code analyzer like FindBugs could also give you some hints.

node.contents: auto un-box is also a possible cause of null pointers.

astNode.text: auto un-box is also a possible cause of null pointers.

node.contents: I did not think of that. I have been on both sides of the fence regarding auto-boxing/unboxing, but I think I might come down on the side saying "as little magic as possible". In other words find out how to have the compiler flag autoboxing usages as errors and explicitly do the conversion manually. I believe the Eclipse compiler can do this, but have not checked.

astNode.text: I did not think of that. I have been on both sides of the fence regarding auto-boxing/unboxing, but I think I might come down on the side saying "as little magic as possible". In other words find out how to have the compiler flag autoboxing usages as errors and explicitly do the conversion manually. I believe the Eclipse compiler can do this, but have not checked.

node.contents: No, the debug information in the class file does not contain enough information to allow this.

astNode.text: No, the debug information in the class file does not contain enough information to allow this.

node.contents: You can, however, improve on the situation. There are two things that can cause a NPE to be thrown:

astNode.text: You can, however, improve on the situation. There are two things that can cause a NPE to be thrown:

node.contents:
• A . dereferencing a variable, like foo.bar().
  • A [ indexing an array, like args[0].

astNode.text:
• A . dereferencing a variable, like foo.bar().
  • A [ indexing an array, like args[0].

node.contents: If you write your code so there is only one of these on a given code line, there is simply no doubt about which one caused the NPE. It will introduce a lot of temporary variables but then you have more information readily available when debugging.

astNode.text: If you write your code so there is only one of these on a given code line, there is simply no doubt about which one caused the NPE. It will introduce a lot of temporary variables but then you have more information readily available when debugging.
